answers.answer: Nearly 6 wks ago I gave birth to my first child, Charlotte Grace. She was taken from the hospital I delivered her at and taken to our capital city,s major childrens hospital. Charlie has been home twice and had to be re-admitted to hospital. eventually Charlie was given an mri scan  which indicated admormatities in  certain areas of her brain. Of course I was devastated but told there was no syndrom or diagnosis, we should just wait and see. One week later charlie was admitted again and after 2 wks in hospital diagnosed initially with Diabetes Insifidus and now Multiple Pituatqary Gland Disorder. She also needs twice daily doses of throxine, decom and another drug which is a replacement of t hormone produced by the pituatry gland. I feel very strongly that not only do I need further information on her condition but perhaps be recomended to support groups for children with this condition.

question: Hello,  I am a 35 year old female.  I got diagnosed with a 3mm pituatary gland tumor a year ago.  I have been lactating for about a year and a half.  In general I don't feel very good fituge.  My concentration is so bad and also memory is too.  I have been to 2 specialist in the last year.  And both say that my Prolacten levels are fine and they also did a run of test on other hormones and all come back ok.  So they are not going to treat it.  They told me if they stopped 100 people walking down the road that 25 of those people would have what I have and not cause any problem.  But as far as I am concerned I do have problems.  My menstrual cycle is messed up but I have an ovarian cyst which is going to be operated on in 4 days.  The lining of my uters is 25mm.  My question is, is this normal treatment just to do nothing?  And also could the pituatary gland tumor be causing the ovarian cyst and uters lining to be thick?  It all sounds so hormonal.
title: pituatary gland tumor
